awd_titl_txt: A Collaborative, Team Science Approach to Transforming STEM Education into an Immersive Research Experience
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by implementing evidence-based teaching practices across four laboratory courses: chemistry, biology, food science, and animal science. National reports have endorsed replacing standard laboratory courses with inquiry-based research experiences that engage students in doing authentic scientific work.  Such opportunities are known to improve student retention in STEM. For example, the value of early opportunities for undergraduates to engage in course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) is widely recognized.  This project will support development and implementation of specific CURE modules in introductory courses across the four disciplines. Six faculty members will create interdisciplinary CURE modules that will involve students in authentic research experiences and help them develop quantitative skills needed to work with large data sets. Students will pursue a primary research project and rotate between instructors and labs for short modules, thus deepening their experiences within the broader interdisciplinary CURE project. The innovative design of linking courses from different disciplines through CUREs has the potential to help students develop broader scientific perspectives about research. 

This project will develop, integrate, and test CURE modules that include interdisciplinary collaborations and unique field-based research on plant cultivation, purification of molecules from the plants, and examination of the molecules’ effects in laboratory studies.  These CUREs will serve more than 200 diverse students, with the potential to have significant positive impact on their success and retention in STEM. The instructors will conduct educational research to investigate the impact of the CUREs on student participants, outcomes of students in CURE-enriched courses versus those in the control sections with traditional labs, and the elements of the experience that had the most impact on student outcomes. Four research questions will be used to measure the effectiveness of CUREs on student academic outcomes and persistence in STEM:   1) To what extent does participation in an interdisciplinary CURE affect academic achievement and retention in STEM? 2) Do students who participate in a CURE have greater improvements in scientific literacy and scientific reasoning skills compared to students in traditional courses? 3) To what extent does participation in an interdisciplinary CURE affect students’ science identity, science motivation and attitudes, and understanding of scientific community values? and 4) How do students’ perceptions of laboratory course design relate to their overall performance?    Answers to these questions will contribute to the body of knowledge about the value of research experiences in undergraduate education, and specifically about a CURE model that involves a research project that spans disciplinary boundaries.  The project intends to increase the students’ academic success and graduation rates and serve as a model for interdisciplinary approaches to active learning and course-based research. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past several years, the CUREs Hemp Initiative Project (CHIP) at Delaware State University, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), has been dedicated to advancing STEM education and preparing the next generation of scientists, innovators, and leaders. Through our collaborative efforts, we have achieved significant outcomes that contribute to both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of our work, as defined by the NSF merit review criteria.

CHIPs focused on redesigning STEM laboratory courses to incorporate authentic research experiences and active learning pedagogies, with the goal of enhancing student engagement, learning outcomes, and retention in STEM majors. We partnered with faculty and graduate students from multiple disciplines to develop innovative curriculum materials and implement experiential learning activities in laboratory settings.

One of the key outcomes of our project is the development and implementation of three redesigned STEM laboratory courses: General Chemistry, Cell Biology, and Introduction to Animal Sciences. These courses integrate authentic research projects related to hemp production, cannabinoid extraction, and potential veterinary or medical applications of cannabinoid extracts. By engaging students in hands-on research experiences, we aimed to foster critical thinking skills, scientific inquiry, and a deeper understanding of complex scientific concepts.

Through rigorous assessment and evaluation, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of our redesigned courses in improving student learning outcomes and engagement. Comparative analyses between traditional and redesigned course sections revealed significant improvements in levels of satisfaction among students in the redesigned courses. Furthermore, qualitative feedback from students highlighted the value of experiential learning in enhancing their understanding of course material and fostering a sense of ownership and excitement for scientific inquiry.

In addition to enhancing student learning experiences, our project has made significant contributions to the broader impacts of STEM education. By disseminating our findings through college research presentations and conferences we have shared our innovative approaches with educators, administrators, and policymakers across the country. Our work has inspired discussions on best practices in STEM pedagogy and prompted other institutions to explore similar strategies for enhancing student engagement and retention in STEM disciplines.

Our project has played a significant role in advancing theoretical frameworks and research methodologies within STEM education research. Through collaborative research efforts, we have deepened our understanding of effective teaching strategies, optimal learning environments, and resulting student outcomes within laboratory settings. Our discoveries have sparked broader discussions about the critical importance of experiential learning, active learning pedagogies, and authentic research experiences in fostering student success and promoting diversity within STEM fields. Over the course of the past three years, we have diligently collected and analyzed data pertaining to our project. Currently, we are in the process of preparing a manuscript for publication in a peer-reviewed journal specializing in science education, pedagogy, and educational research. This forthcoming publication will offer comprehensive analyses of our project's methodologies, outcomes, and implications for teaching and learning across STEM disciplines.

 

 

The CHIPs project has fostered interdisciplinary collaborations and partnerships within and beyond academia. By bringing together faculty, students, and stakeholders from diverse disciplines, we have created opportunities for interdisciplinary dialogue, knowledge exchange, and collaborative research projects. These partnerships have enriched our project outcomes and expanded the scope of our impact, enabling us to address complex societal challenges through innovative STEM education initiatives.

Looking ahead, our project outcomes will continue to inform and shape the future of STEM education. By integrating experiential learning experiences, active learning pedagogies, and authentic research projects into laboratory courses, we aim to inspire the next generation of scientists and innovators to tackle the grand challenges facing our world. Through sustained collaboration and dissemination efforts, we are committed to advancing STEM education and empowering students to make meaningful contributions to society.

In conclusion, the CHIPs project has achieved significant outcomes that address both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of STEM education. By redesigning laboratory courses, conducting rigorous research, and disseminating our findings, we have made valuable contributions to the advancement of STEM education and the preparation of future generations of STEM professionals. Our work underscores the importance of innovative teaching practices, experiential learning, and interdisciplinary collaboration in shaping the future of STEM education for a sustainable and inclusive society.
